p: Lisa M. Maillart is an Assistant Professor in the Industrial Engineering Department at the University of Pittsburgh. Prior to joining the faculty at Pitt, she served on the faculty at Case Western Reserve University. She received her M.S., and B.S. in industrial and systems engineering from Virginia Tech, and her Ph.D. in industrial and operations engineering from the University of Michigan. Her primary research interest is in sequential decision making under uncertainty, with applications in medical decision making, and maintenance optimization. She is a member of INFORMS, SMDM, and IIE.

p: C. Richard Cassady is a Professor in the Department of Industrial Engineering and Director of Freshman Engineering at the University of Arkansas. Prior to joining the faculty at the UofA, he was on the faculty at Mississippi State University. He received his Ph.D. in industrial and systems engineering from Virginia Tech. His primary reliability research interests are in repairable systems modeling, and preventive maintenance optimization. He is a Senior Member of IIE; and a member of ASEE, INFORMS, and SRE. He is also a member of the RAMS Management Committee.

p: Chase Rainwater is a Ph.D. student at the University of Florida in the Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering. Prior to his graduate studies, he obtained a B.S. in industrial engineering at the University of Arkansas. His primary research interests are in supply chain optimization with specific applications to production planning decision models. He is a member of IIE, and INFORMS.

p: Kellie Schneider is a Ph.D. student in the Department of Industrial Engineering, and an instructor in the Freshman Engineering Program at the University of Arkansas. She received her M.S., and B.S. in Industrial Engineering from the U of A. Her primary research interests are in reliability, and maintenance modeling. She is a member if IEEE, and IIE.

details.abstract: ¿Selective maintenance¿ models determine the optimal subset of desirable maintenance actions to perform when maintenance resources are constrained. We analyse a corrective selective maintenance model that identifies which components to replace in the finitely long periods of time between missions performed by a series-parallel system. We formulate this multi-mission problem as a stochastic dynamic program, and compare the resulting optimal infinite-horizon policy to both the optimal single-mission, and two-mission policies by executing a large numerical experiment. Our results indicate that these policies rarely differ, and that when they do, the difference in long-run mission reliability is minimal, which suggests that future work should concentrate on extending results for the single-mission problem.
